content.title: Hand Washing
details: • 20 seconds (typically the chorus of a song), rubbing between fingers, over tops and palms, and under nail beds.
• Antibacterial soap or alcohol-based sanitizer.
• Avoid scalding hot water that may dry out skin, this may create microtears in the skin’s protective barrier.

content.title: General Tips
details: • Avoid touching your face, become conscious of how often you do.
• Because COVID-19 can transmit to the eyes, avoid wearing contact lenses that may trap contaminants if possible. Wear traditional glasses instead.
• Routinely sanitize personal belongings (phones, wallets, keys, glasses) and high contact surfaces (handles, counters, car steering wheels).
• Cover your coughs and sneezes with your elbow, facing away from others.
• Avoid handshaking and hugs when greeting others professionally and socially.
• Everybody should create and wear a mask when they must leave their home.
• N95 masks should ONLY be used in those showing symptoms, or those around the potentially infected.
• Surfaces: COVID-19 can live on fabrics and hard surface for a predicted period of several days, clean surfaces routinely with disinfectants.

sources.title: Michigan Health
sources.headline: Flattening the Curve for COVID-19: What Does It Mean and How Can You Help?

content.title: General Tips
details: Social distancing is advised to prevent an exponential infection of the American people. As observed in Italy and China, ICUs and ventilators are not infinite.
• Avoid large gatherings and close-contact environments (including gyms).
• Worry, concern, frustration, and loneliness are expected: remind yourself of the greater good you are promoting and advocating for by social distancing.
• Those previously experiencing substance abuse and mental health concern may be more likely to struggle in social isolation, consult appropriate providers/resources.
• Employees/students are advised to work from home/participate in online courses.
• If you absolutely must leave the house, support small businesses.

content.title: Stigmatization
details: Fear of infection has led to patterns of harmful stereotyping and stigmatization of certain Americans.
Recent travelers, healthcare workers, and those of Asian descent are at risk of stigmatization.
Stigmatized populations are subject to social rejection, denial of resources, and verbal and/or physical violence.
Want to fight stigma? Support members of your community who may suffer from fear-induced discrimination
Take action: share your knowledge to dissolve myths and combat stereotypes
Stress and stigma affects us all differently; those with a history of mental health or substance abuse issues may be at higher risk.
If you or someone you know may be struggling, reach out. Local and national resources are usually available if you need advice.

content.title: Two Week's Supply
details: • If you display symptoms, you are advised to self-quarantine for two weeks; develop a two week’s supply of food, medical and cleaning supplies needed in the event you must self-quarantine.
• Plan ahead for prescriptions and essential medical supply needs.
• If you are healthy and able, consider making the trip to build a supply for the immunocompromised and/or older adults in your community.
• If stores are out of stock of staples, online retailers may still deliver.

content.title: When in Stores
details: • Sanitize your carts and hands; many retailers have stations with disinfectant and cleaning supplies but you can also bring your own to be sure.
• Avoid proximity and interaction with other customers.
• Thank the employees! They are working around the clock to keep shelves stocked.

content.title: Vulnerable Populations
details: • Experts currently believe that members of non-vulnerable populations typically suffer only mild symptoms.
• Vulnerable populations (adults older than 65 and those with pre-existing conditions) are at greater risk of severe symptoms and complications.
• Vulnerable populations may need emergency health services if infected.
• Hospitalization, ICU (intensive care unit) treatment, specific experimental drugs and ventilator intubation have all been used with the most severe COVID-19 cases.
• Treatment resources and personal protective equipment are high in demand due to global spread of the coronavirus which causes COVID-19.

content.title: If a Vulnerable Population Member Shows Symptoms
details: • Call ahead to emergency health services so they can anticipate arrival.
• Call local healthcare provider and/or health department to seek testing and professional guidance.
